author: @cliffmathew
text: About RGB values: Imagine each tiny dot on the screen to be a set of 3 small light bulbs: one Red, one Green and the other Blue. When all 3 are OFF, all light is absent, and the point is Black. The 0,0,0 is telling the computer to turn off  all 3 lights, one zero per light, 0 indicating the off position of an imaginary dial. If you tell the computer to light all lights at full intensity, then it will show White light, combining Red, Green and Blue (assuming you look from a certain distance where you can't see each bulb separately, and they all blur into a single point).  When you dial down all 3 switches to  0,0,0, all are off, and you see Black. When you dial each switch up to its full value,  255,255,255, all 3 are at its full intensity, and hence you see  White. If you adjust those numbers individually, you control the intensity of each bulb,  giving you different colors. Hope it helps some readers.

It reflects back red "light" and hence appears red. Similarly for Blue, Green and the whole VIBGYOR spectrum.   * So, when you mix all colors of paint - the mixture tends to absorb all spectrum and reflect none, thereby appearing black.  * But, when you mix all colors of light - the mixture combines to give white which, by definition, contains the whole spectrum. author: @mage1over137
text: You shouldn't use white for transparent, because there is a very good chance you'll use white in  your sprites. Usually an ugly pink is used (rgb(244, 66, 235) works well). For simple sprite it's not a big deal, because you only need to use a color not used in the sprite, but if you doing a very complicated sprite sheet, there is a good chance white is used, but choosing a weird color probably not. It should also be noted if you using rgb color mode and not argb color mode, then for transparency  works by ignoring a single color is rgb value isfor every sprite, so choosing an ugly color, and not using that color for any part of your game you can maintain compatibility between the two modes, which is something you might want to do.   The reason that rgb mode has to ignore a color in order to have a transparent layer comes down to the fact that there just isn't room on a 24bit value(8 bits per color) for transparent to be encoded without sacrificing another color. You might wonder why pink is used and not say almost black(1,0,0) or black (0,0,0). These colors are basically the same, and you can choose to use only of the, but the ugly pink is probably going to be father removed from any color you decide to use and therefor offer nice contrast background. Or another way to think about it, why throw away a black I can use for a gradient effect, when I can throw away a pink in the middle of some other ugly pinks that probably won't every be used.

author: @mage1over137
text: +sentdex The word you were looking for is with pigments subtractive color, while screens and projectors use additive color. What happens since most object don't produce their own light(at least in visible range), the color we see is the light that's reflected, while all the colors get absorbed. On the other hand screens project their own color, which means the waveforms add together.
